docs.lead_paragraph: In the last decade, dozens of scientists have claimed they have found evidence of links between religion and health, and the idea has caught on. News articles with headlines like ''Spirituality Is Good Medicine'' and ''The Prayer Cure'' have reported the findings as if they added up to just another instance of science confirming the obvious: that spiritual faith helps people stay healthy and live longer. More than 70 medical schools offer instruction in how to address patients' religious beliefs. An H.M.O. in Denver offers spiritual counseling to all members. And doctors are beginning to cross the traditional divide between religion and medicine.

headline.main: Religion and Health: New Research Revives an Old Debate

docs.abstract: Article on Columbia University psychologist Dr Richard P Sloan's contention that popular scientific research seemingly confirming link between religion and health is rife with methodological problems and statistical flaws; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In the last decade, dozens of scientists have claimed they have found evidence of links between religion and health, and the idea has caught on. News articles with headlines like ''Spirituality Is Good Medicine'' and ''The Prayer Cure'' have reported...

docs.lead_paragraph: Strains of gonorrhea that are resistant to a major class of antibiotics have reached the mainland United States after steady migration from Asia to Hawaii and now to California. Meanwhile in Hawaii, researchers have identified the first cases in the United States of gonorrhea resistant to multiple drugs. The standard mainland treatment calls for single-dose therapy using one of two classes of antibiotics, fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin and the cephalosporins cefixime and ceftriaxone. But resistance to fluoroquinolones is now found in 60 percent to 80 percent of cases in some East Asian countries and 20 percent of those in Hawaii, where fluoroquinolone use has been largely abandoned.

headline.main: New Resistant Gonorrhea Migrating to Mainland U.S.

docs.abstract: Officials at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, scheduling meeting to address problem and announce new guidelines, say strains of gonorrhea resistant to fluoroquinolone class of antibiotics have reached US mainland after migrating from Asia to Hawaii; researchers in Hawaii identify first cases in US of gonorrhea resistant to multiple drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a young child has an ear infection, many parents are not satisfied unless they leave the doctor's office with a prescription for antibiotics, even though the infections almost always clear up by themselves and the overuse of antibiotics poses a public health problem. A new study offers a possible solution, a ''safety net'' prescription. It was presented yesterday at a meeting of the Pediatric Academic Societies in Baltimore.
docs.abstract: Study by researchers at Children's Hospital Medical Center in Cincinnati, presented at Pediatric Academic Societies meeting in Baltimore, describes experiment in which parents who sought treatment for children's ear infections were asked to wait 48 hours before filling prescriptions for antibiotics and reported that use of pain medications was effective; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: When a young child has an ear infection, many parents are not satisfied unless they leave the doctor's office with a prescription for antibiotics, even though the infections almost always clear up by themselves and the overuse of antibiotics poses a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Matthew Jasper, 35, a poet from Farmington, N.H., had a brainstorm. After the birth of his second child, he said to his wife, ''Next time why don't we do this by ourselves?''

headline.main: When Giving Birth, Opting to Go It Alone

docs.abstract: Article on Beatrice and Matthew Jasper of Farmington, NH, and small, close-knit network of parents across US and abroad who are choosing unassisted childbirth; doctors and nurse-midwives oppose such births, citing serious complications that could result; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Matthew Jasper, 35, a poet from Farmington, N.H., had a brainstorm.     After the birth of his second child, he said to his wife, ''Next time why don't we do this by ourselves?''

docs.lead_paragraph: A college student who knew she was allergic to peanuts died after eating chili that had been thickened with peanut butter. Another college student died after eating cookies with a label that failed to mention peanuts as an ingredient because the manufacturer, not wanting to waste some leftover peanut cookie batter, added it to the batter for some other kind of cookie. A 15-year-old died on a Connecticut sidewalk after eating a piece of coffee cake that she thought was free of peanuts. A 14-year-old on a camping trip died after eating a sandwich made with a knife used to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

headline.main: Dodging Peanuts: To Some, a Lifelong Challenge

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on lifelong challenges that both children and adults with potentially deadly peanut allergies face in determining what foods are safe to eat; describes symptoms and treatments; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: High levels of folate, the B vitamin found in foods like citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, beans and grain products, can lower the risk of stroke, a new study reports. The study -- in Stroke, a journal of the American Heart Association -- said the findings were the first to link folate with the health benefit.

headline.main: A New Reason to Eat Your Beans

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Lydia Bazzano and colleagues at Tulane School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine, published in journal Stroke, finds that high levels of folate, B-vitamin found in foods like citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, beans and grains products, can lower risk of stroke (M)
docs.snippet: High levels of folate, the B vitamin found in foods like citrus fruits, leafy green vegetables, beans and grain products, can lower the risk of stroke, a new study reports.    The study -- in Stroke, a journal of the American Heart Association --...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lori Rice was 10 when she started menstruating, and every month was an ordeal. ''I was having a lot of problems with my period -- cramping and heavy bleeding,'' said Lori, now 15. ''The pain was the worst. I missed a lot of school, and it got worse the longer I had my period.'' Her mother, Kathy Rice, took Lori to their family doctor, who prescribed heat, ibuprofen and calcium supplements. Heat gave Lori some relief, but it was not always a practical or sufficient solution.

headline.main: Beyond Birth Control: The Pill Tackles New Duties

docs.abstract: Article on trend toward treating adolescent and teenage girls suffering from menstrual cramping, heavy bleeding and other symptoms of dysmenorrhea with oral contraceptives; Dr Anne R Davis of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York is conducting first study of oral contraceptives in treatment of adolescent menstrual pain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Teaching new mothers how to use ''controlled crying'' techniques, sometimes known as Ferberizing, can improve not just the babies' sleep, but also the women's well-being, a new study reports. ''This brief community-based sleep intervention decreased infant sleep problems and symptoms of maternal depression,'' wrote the researchers, who published their findings yesterday in The British Medical Journal.
docs.abstract: Study by researchers at Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne, Australia, published in British Medical Journal, finds that teaching new mothers how to use 'controlled crying' techniques can improve babies' sleep and women's well-being (M)
docs.snippet: Teaching new mothers how to use ''controlled crying'' techniques, sometimes known as Ferberizing, can improve not just the babies' sleep, but also the women's well-being, a new study reports.    ''This brief community-based sleep intervention...

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans lack immunity to tetanus and diphtheria because they fail to follow federal guidelines that call for regular booster shots against the diseases, a new study finds. The study, released yesterday by The Annals of Internal Medicine, found that many Americans were immunized against tetanus and diphtheria early in their lives, but became vulnerable to infection by skipping the boosters. The lead author, Dr. Geraldine M. McQuillan of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and her colleagues said doctors needed to be more aggressive about immunizing.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study published in Annals of Internal Medicine finds that millions of Americans lack immunity to tetanus and diphtheria because they have not had booster shots every 10 years; drawing (M)
